title: Modeling EA-CSF, Sleep, and Social Outcomes in Early Childhood

media.caption: Line graph of predicted and observed EA-CSF volumes in 231 infants. Each point represents a visit, and each line represents a subject. Age is centered at 24 months, indicated by the red line (X = 0) on the X-axis. The predicted values (orange lines) are overlaid on observed EA-CSF volumes (variations of blue).
Line graph depicting differences in brain volume growth of infants with and without sleep dysregulation.
Line graph of 184 infants' brain volume from ages 0 to 36 months.

sections.heading: Project Overview
sections.content: Investigated whether extra-axial cerebrospinal fluid (EA-CSF) mediates the effect of early sleep disturbances on social communication outcomes in early development (n=400; ages 0–5).

sections.heading: Dataset
items: **Source:** Baby Connectome Project (400 infants across 10 timepoints)
**Measures:** Sleep ratings, structural MRI, social/language assessments

sections.heading: Methods
items: **Modeling:** Structural Equation Modeling and Latent growth curve modeling (Mplus, R)
**Statistical Testing:** SEM to evaluate mediation
**Neuroimaging:** EA-CSF volume from T1 MRI (24 months)

sections.heading: Technologies Used
items: **Analysis:** Mplus, R
**Data Handling:** tidyr and dplyr on R, SQL, Neuroimaging: Bash pipelines

sections.heading: Key Findings
items: No evidence for EA-CSF mediating sleep/social outcomes
Elevated EA-CSF linked to lower receptive language and social reciprocity at 24 months
Sleep trajectories alone not predictive of social outcomes or EA-CSF ratios

sections.heading: Impact
sections.content: Clarified EA-CSF’s non-mediating role, highlighting need for multidimensional longitudinal models.

sections.heading: Data Access
sections.content: Due to ongoing publication, I am unable to share full data. However, you can view my dissertation at [Purdue Hammer](https://hammer.purdue.edu/articles/thesis/Sleep_and_developmental_risks_The_roles_of_extra-axial_cerebrospinal_fluid/20334816?file=36356652).

title: Systematic Review of Sleep, CSF Circulation, and Glymphatic System Function in Various Pathologies
cite: Chong, P. L., Garic, D., Shen, M. D., Lundgaard, I., & Schwichtenberg, A. J. (2022).

media.caption: Example of the bubble plot in the study depicting correlations, age, and effect sizes drawn from studies that assess sleep and orexin.
Example of the bubble plot in the study depicting correlations, age, and effect sizes drawn from studies that assess sleep and amyloid-beta.

sections.heading: Project Overview
sections.content: Analyzed how sleep disturbances affect CSF circulation and glymphatic system (GS) function across neurodegenerative, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric conditions. Addressed variability in study designs.

sections.heading: Approach
items: **Dataset:** 190 peer-reviewed studies (n = 19,129)
**Key Variables:** CSF metabolites (amyloid-β, tau), sleep metrics, GS function
**Methods:** Automated data extraction and correlation modeling (R)

sections.heading: Technologies Used
items: **Analysis:** R
**Data Handling:** tidyr, dplyr
**Visualization:** ggplot2

sections.heading: Challenges
sections.content: Methodological variation across studies complicated standardization. Advanced statistical controls were needed to extract reliable associations.

sections.heading: Key Findings
items: Sleep disturbances associated with shifts in amyloid-β and tau levels
Relationships varied across clinical populations
Visual patterns suggest possible GS-related biomarkers

sections.heading: Impact
sections.content: Findings support the need for standardized GS measures and deeper analysis of sleep-CSF interactions in brain disorders.

sections.heading: Data Access
sections.content: You can access the publication at [PubMed Central](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8821419/) for detailed findings.

title: Sleep Deficiency & Autonomic Dysregulation in Children with Autism
cite: Chong, P. L. H., Abel, E., Pao, R., McCormick, C. E. B., & Schwichtenberg, A. J. (2021).

media.caption: Line graph depicting the difference in frequency of NCSSCRs and accelerometer between children with and without regulated sleep across the day.
Line graph depicting the difference in frequency of NCSSCRs and accelerometer in each child.

sections.heading: Project Overview
sections.content: Studied the effect of sleep deficiency on autonomic function in children with autism using electrodermal activity (EDA) as a physiological marker.

sections.heading: Approach
items: **Dataset:** 13 children with autism
**Measures:** EDA collected via ankle/wrist sensors, sleep actigraphy, and sleep assessments
**Analysis:** Ledalab (MATLAB), R, SPSS

sections.heading: Technologies Used
items: **Signal Processing:** Ledalab for EDA
**Statistical Tools:** R, SPSS
**Visualization:** ggplot2

sections.heading: Challenges
sections.content: Mapping EDA to sleep regulation was complex due to variability in autonomic patterns.

sections.heading: Key Findings
items: Sleep-deficient children showed reduced tonic/phasic EDA signals
Autonomic dysregulation tied to both sleep and autism severity

sections.heading: Impact
sections.content: Supports further study into how sleep affects autonomic and behavioral regulation in ASD.

sections.heading: Data Access
sections.content: You can access the publication [here](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/00221325.2021.1911919?casa_token=zLgUTqALB5kAAAAA:QrQGnxm3OK3ig1-nt66D4Fxp8e1xWFdzZ7q_l2tXFmMBKoXbcQDa_XXz706PuMD9tYjGyL7Zir0AGdKi) for detailed findings.

title: Capturing developmentally consequential sleep dysregulation within the Baby Connectome Project

media.caption: Individual trajectories of sleep problems in 323 infants across the first two years of life. Estimated intercept means were generated at ten time points using sleep problem scores derived from four parent-report measures. Scores above 0 indicate having more sleep problems than average, below 0 indicate fewer problems.

sections.heading: Project Overview
sections.content: Classified infant sleep trajectories using latent growth curve modeling on parent-reported data across 10 time points.

sections.heading: Approach
items: **Dataset:** Baby Connectome Study (10 time points, 323 children, 949 reports)
**Methods:** Latent growth curve modeling on sleep scores from four parent-report questionnaires

sections.heading: Technologies Used
items: **Modeling:** Mplus, R
**Data Wrangling:** tidyr, dplyr in R

sections.heading: Challenges
sections.content: Standardizing sleep reports and modeling consistent vs. transient sleep issues.

sections.heading: Key Findings
items: Identified sleep trajectories for 323 infants using model-estimated intercepts/slopes
Classified 35 infants (10%) with persistent sleep problems and 288 with transient/no issues
Findings align with known prevalence rates of childhood sleep dysregulation

sections.heading: Impact
sections.content: Offers replicable method for early sleep classification and groundwork for linking sleep to brain development.

sections.heading: Data Access
sections.content: Due to ongoing publication, I am unable to provide full access to the data and analysis at this time. However, you can view details on this study from the appendix section of my dissertation at [Purdue Hammer](https://hammer.purdue.edu/articles/thesis/Sleep_and_developmental_risks_The_roles_of_extra-axial_cerebrospinal_fluid/20334816?file=36356652).

sections.content: Creating a pricing calculator after scraping the web for updated precious metal prices.

title: Task Cat: A Simple Reward-Based To-Do List

media.caption: A screenshot of the To-Do App.
A video demonstrating Task Cat in action.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: I wanted to create a to-do list that was not overwhelming with all the tags, subtasks, and categories and had a mini reward for each task completion.

sections.heading: My Solution
items: A minimalist to-do list focused on just today's tasks and the near future.
Stores tasks locally (persists across sessions).
Removes completed tasks automatically.
Surprise reward — completing a task reveals a cute cat image.

sections.heading: Technologies Used
items: Local Storage to save tasks
CSS for a clean UI
Uses Cataas API

sections.heading: Challenges & Learnings
items: Managing state efficiently without overcomplicating the UI.
Implementing persistent storage for tasks.

sections.heading: Future Improvements
items: Dark mode for better accessibility.
More animations for the cat reward.
Optional task categories (without clutter).

sections.heading: Data Access
sections.content: Check it out on GitHub: [Note Taking API](https://github.com/pearlynne/DailyToDoListAPI).

media.caption: Overview of user reports
Patient profile and details view
Summary of patient's submitted reports
Summary statistics on user's mood ratings

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: A mental health tracking API designed for therapy users and providers. Users log daily reports, helping them recall events and identify triggers. Providers use this data to offer personalized insights.

sections.heading: Key Features
items: **Authentication & Authorization:** Secure login for users & providers
**Behavioral Tracking:** Log mood, symptoms & medication reactions
**Appointment Management:** Schedule & manage appointments
**Data Insights:** Aggregate statistics for mood trends

sections.heading: Tech Stack
items: **Backend:** Express.js, MongoDB, Mongoose
**Security:** JWT authentication, bcrypt hashing
**Data Handling:** Indexed MongoDB, text search
**Testing:** Jest for unit tests

sections.heading: Challenges & Solutions
items: **Data Privacy:** Role-based authorization to control access
**Efficient Search:** Indexed DB & text search for fast retrieval
**Handling Large Data:** Optimized MongoDB queries

sections.heading: Outcome & Next Steps
sections.content: The API streamlines mental health tracking. Future improvements include a frontend interface and advanced data analytics.

sections.heading: Data Access
sections.content: Check it out on GitHub: [Health Tracking API](https://github.com/pearlynne/HealthTrackingAPI).

media.caption: Product page
Shopping cart
Contact form
Login page
Sign up page

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: A small bespoke jewelry business app that enables users to browse products, create accounts, manage carts, and track purchases. Built to replace third-party platforms like Etsy, giving full control over the business.

sections.heading: Key Features
items: Fetches shop inventory from Firebase
Renders product image, title, description, and price
Allows users to add products to cart
Allows users to view shopping cart
Allows purchase confirmation (without payment gateway service)
Writes purchase details to Firebase, updating inventory and account information
Creates user account
Authenticates user account with Firebase

sections.heading: Tech Stack
items: **Frontend:** React, React Router
**Backend:** Firebase (Authentication, Database, Hosting)
**Testing:** Vitest, React Testing Library

sections.heading: Challenges & Solutions
items: Firebase hosting setup was complex and required further reading on GitHub deployment.
Adjusting data structures was necessary to support real-time updates.
Filtering purchases based on authentication required modifying fetch logic.

sections.heading: Future Improvements
items: Implement product galleries to support multiple images per product.
Integrate a payment gateway such as Stripe or PayPal.
Add a search function to allow users to find products by name.

sections.heading: Data Access
sections.content: Check it out live: [Firebase Hosting](https://etal-ecomm.web.app/).
